required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intraoperative Nerve Monitoring During Robot-assisted Laparoscopic Prostatectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Assessment of Intraoperative Nerve Monitoring During Robot-assisted Laparoscopic Prostatectomy

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the use of intraoperative nerve monitoring during robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy surgery improves post-surgery urinary continence and erectile function.

primary_outcome.measure: Return of urinary continence following robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy
primary_outcome.description: The proportion of subjects who have urinary continence following robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy (RALP) at 6 months postoperatively.

secondary_outcome.measure: Return of erectile function following robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy
secondary_outcome.time_frame: catheter removal which typically occurs at 1 week, 1 month, 3 month, 6 month, 12 month
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of subjects who return to pre-operative baseline (RTB) category (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, or severe erectile dysfunction) of erectile function following RALP with IONM of pelvic nerves. The change in SHIM score over time from baseline to 12 months.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: catheter removal which typically occurs at 1 week, 1 month, 3 month, 6 month, 12 month
secondary_outcome.description: Assess time to continence defined as using 0 pads per day following RALP with IONM of pelvic nerves for 12 month post-operatively.

arm_group.description: Patients for which intraoperative nerve monitoring (electromyography) is used to identify the location of somatic pelvic nerves critical to urinary continence control and erectile function in real time during robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy surgery

intervention.description: Intraoperative nerve monitoring (electromyography) is used to identify the location of somatic pelvic nerves critical to urinary continence control and erectile function in real time during robotic-assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy surgery
